**I think it hit me at some point during the Uber ride to her house: this could be the most important hook-up in human history. And the scariest. I know it sounds stupid and indulgent to say that, especially coming from another hetero-normative dude in black Christian Diors like me. (Whatever, they were knock-offs.) But given the extraordinary features of this interaction, along with its consequences for how people think of themselves, I really donâ€™t think itâ€™s an exaggeration. All of this is true by the way. I donâ€™t have the time to make any of this up, and frankly I sucked pretty bad in Language Arts. My grade-school teachers will bug out if they read this.**Â 

**My band was doing a show in Salt Lake Cityâ€“you know, Mormon utopia in the middle of the desert. Our next gig in Boise had been cancelled for reasons we didnâ€™t entirely understand. When youâ€™re on the road you just kind of run with things, I guess. We decided to hang out in Utah for a couple of days. Somebody said we could â€œbackpack in the watercolor meadows of the Uintahsâ€. Sounded like a good time. We do retrowave electronica stuff, lots of synthy sounds with flashing lights and voice effects. Everyoneâ€™s into the eighties again, even the Mormons it turns out.**Â 

**I still donâ€™t think of myself as a hook-up guy, even after all these years on the road. Iâ€™m serious. Itâ€™s not something I enjoy or even particularly like. I see hook-ups as one of the rites of being a traveling musician, or maybe even a curse. Itâ€™s like how prime ministers have to shake hands with people they donâ€™t necessarily like. Iâ€™m a reluctant diplomat of the grunge scene. Everything that guys like David Bowie did make total sense to me. They turned their lives upside-down just to try and find something real. I wonder if they ever found itâ€“when I did, it scared the crap out of me.**Â 

**The first Tinder girl I met in Utah was one of those â€œitâ€™s for a good causeâ€-type chicks. Iâ€™m not trying to offend anybody, itâ€™s just the only way I can think to describe her. What annoys me about those girls is that they all have the same personality. Theyâ€™re almost breathless to prove how angry they are about all the *right* things. It makes me feel like everything I know is wrong or something. You just sit there and listen and drown in their syndicated outrage. I swiped right for shallow reasons, yes. The messed-up thing is that I anticipated my annoyance as I glanced at her pics. I was shamelessly undeterred.**Â 

**Her peach spaghetti-strap top swallowed most of my attention, even as she soliloquized about non binary love and dying pandas. (OK, I made that last one up.) Her blonde hair was pulled back in a ponytail. It was less a conversation and more a kind of reciting on her partâ€“anyone couldâ€™ve been sitting in front of her. I wonder if she wouldâ€™ve acted differently if she knew who I was. A few hours later, I finished softly somewhere in the bobbing bramble of hair in my lap. It was depressing. She fixed her ponytail in the mirror, checked her phone, then quickly left.**Â 

**I donâ€™t usually let people get to know me too well, not even my bandmates. I mean we drop acid together sometimes, bro-bonding stuff, that kind of thing. Thatâ€™s about it. Even with girls, Iâ€™m a sex-in-the-dark kind of dude. They probably think Iâ€™m weird but I never ask. When the peach-top pedant was leaving I gave her one of our albums on cassette tape. It was awkward (â€œUh, thanksâ€¦?â€) but I feel like itâ€™s the best I can do.**Â 

**Somewhere in the discussion of her saintly works, she had mentioned something her uncle had seen in a mall near downtown Salt Lake City. It was like an upright human with amphibian skin or something. Her uncle was a janitor who cleaned floors there late at night. The thing had come out of a basement stairwell, looked at him for a moment, then turned right back around and disappeared. The really crazy thing was that her uncle said he felt some kind of emotion deep in his chest that he never felt before, sort of like how you feel when you lock eyes with a stranger that looks inexplicably familiar. She reported all of this as a joke, rattling it off at blinding speed in her machine-gun dialogue of goodspeak. I couldnâ€™t stop thinking about it for the rest of the night, though, even when we started making out.**Â 

**The guys in our band like to joke about the golden thumbâ€“itâ€™s when you start a streak of matching with the cityâ€™s hottest women. Thatâ€™s millennial serendipity at its finest. Isaac had the golden thumb in Topeka and we didnâ€™t see him until Michigan, but in Michigan the algorithms failed him. It works in mysterious ways. When I matched with this Clarissa girl from Provo, I decided Salt Lake City *was* a promised land, or at least my own Topeka. I had no idea what I was getting myself into, nor has that condition of not-knowing changed. But let me back up...**

**Clarissa was one of those one-pic profiles, which is risky. Youâ€™re betting that this single picture is so alluring that the opposite swiper needs no further proof of your hotness. In her case, it was a win. She was wearing a black romper striped orange, yellow, green; her hair was blue and cut boyishly short. The obligatory septum piercing made her nose look like a jewelled accessory. Style, attitude, cuteness. Bad-ass but delicate. The interesting part: the picture wasnâ€™t a picture but actually a moving boomerang, one of those images perpetually repeating two seconds of movement.**

**The boomerang showed Clarissa from behind, jogging in-place on a sidewalk with her face looking coyly back into the camera. I donâ€™t need to mention the advantages such an angle affords those of the requisite affinitiesâ€“but there was something else. Something *else.* There looked to be a kind of independent movement beneath the fabric around her tailbone, like an appendage that was rising and falling as she ran. You could *just* make out the outline. It couldnâ€™t beâ€¦**

**I put my phone away and started pumping some beat-mixes to get my mind straight. Things couldnâ€™t be *that* freaky in Utah. My headphones werenâ€™t loud enough to block out the image. The thing that bothered me most was that my attraction to her hadnâ€™t waned; if anything, I felt *more* attracted. Had I been watching too many shapeshifter animes? That was probably the case regardless.**Â 

**Even so, there was no doubt that Clarissaâ€™s festive romper was hiding a full-grown tailâ€“like, none at all.Â  I watched the boomerang over and over again, turning my phone this way and that. There was no other conclusion. I considered calling my bandmates for brotherly support but in the end opted for privacy. Imagine if they heard I was seeing a girl with a *tail.* Literally a tail dangling down her rear. Her caption read: â€œWyoming-raised, Utah-grown. I donâ€™t want to go to Paris or Prague. Take me to a hidden place we can share secrets.â€ It was just too much.**Â 

**The first time I met Clarissa it was somewhere near State St. Itâ€™s hard for me to keep track of the roads because theyâ€™re all numbered on a grid based on their proximity to the Mormon temple. Clarissa told me that this system makes it easier to get around and not get lost. She laughed when I disagreed. We ate vegan wraps in one of those generic Salt Lake plazas made of Mexican eateries and Asian stores. Clarissa explained that she ate healthy when it suited her schedule and mood, which made her â€œa seasonal veganâ€. It was summertime in Salt Lake; she wore a dirty-green tank-top and gray denim shorts ripped across the thighs; her hair was bluer than Freddie Mercuryâ€™s stage lighting.**Â 

**She was one of those girls who was easy to talk to, but from whom you couldnâ€™t allow your attention to waver. Clarissa was no prolific talker. Instead I got a watchful loner vibe, someone youâ€™d see walking along deserted railroad tracks, someone who considered Bjork their private therapist. I kept imagining how I could bring the topic up without coming across as a total creep. â€œI didnâ€™t know people in Utah had tails...is that common here?â€ Gross. Maybe something more personal. â€œThat romper you had on does a lot for your tail.â€ God, no. I settled on: â€œCan you show me that running move from your profile?â€**Â 

**We were walking along the sidewalks in the glow of the street lamps; night had fallen on the strange city made of numbers. Clarissaâ€™s hand was clasped softly in mine. I kept resisting the temptation to look behind her like an idiot. She was pressing me with questions somewhat absently. When I told her my bandâ€™s name was Nineteeneightyfornicate, she lost it and started going through all of our pictures on Instagram. That name was Isaacâ€™s idea, not mine! It did have a nice ring to it.**Â 

**She stopped walking and turned on me suddenly.**

**â€œYou know, donâ€™t you?â€**

**â€œKnowâ€“know what?â€ I stammered lamely.**Â 

**â€œOh come off the bullshit, man. Youâ€™ve known this whole time.â€ Staring me frankly in the eyes, she took my hand and ran it along something long, firm, cylindrical on her backside. My heartbeat quickened and a soft moan emitted from my throat. Clarissa giggled and threw my hand away.**Â 

**â€œAny secrets youâ€™d like to share with me?â€**Â 

**I looked at her for a second, processing. â€œI already told you my dirty band nameâ€“â€**

**â€œRight,â€ she scoffed. â€œI hope you come up with something better by tomorrow.â€**

**She turned and began receding into the jasmine-bordered shadows. I realized that we had been surrounded by cats ever since we started walking. They now trailed her in unison like a row of ducklings down the sidewalk.**Â 

**â€œI DIDNâ€™T KNOW YOU WERE A CAT PERSON!â€ I yelled hopelessly.**Â 

**She laughed and raised a long middle finger into the air without turning around. I sighed and began walking in the other direction back to my hotel. I opened my phone to a new text message from Clarissa. It didnâ€™t say anything; sheâ€™d only sent three cat emojis with their tails in the air. I marveled at how little I knew what in the hell was going on. *I just stroked a human tail. That really happened.* And yet, perversely, I couldnâ€™t wait for the next day.**Â 

***....Any secrets youâ€™d like to share with meâ€¦***

**Iâ€™ll come cleanâ€“that night wasnâ€™t the first time I googled â€œhumans with tailsâ€. There had been drunken nights alone that I obsessed over the idea. My thoughts were ransacked by half-humanoids risen from primordial tetrapods, dripping with sea-foam and tails dragging in the sand. I told you I was a weird guy. To this point, the greatest harm all this had done was butcher my online algorithmsâ€“I would get ads for kinky Halloween costumes, which routinely raised some eyebrows.**Â 

***She could be a government spy on some troll-job,* I thought to myself. The idea tormented me for several hours. What was worse, I thought, the CIA using search history and store-bought accessories to play with my mind, or the possibility that I had met some kind of hybrid human with a rope of flesh swinging from her backside? The little bit of ganja I had left made my speculations thicker and more confusing. She had to be real. Why would the government waste time mind-fucking a guy from a band named Nineteeneightyfornicate? I went from that to wondering what she ate when she was stoned.**Â Â 

**Before I knew it, I was stepping out onto the curb in front of her house in my black knock-off Christian Diors. Who was this profane intruder in Provo? An agent *provo*cateur, I grinned to myself. I didnâ€™t know there could be neighborhoods with trees in the desert. Seemed like the Mormons were pretty good landscapers when they werenâ€™t busy granting all their wives eternal life. Who knew! Clarissa lived in a blue house with a quaint little front porch, one of those places that really has the picture-book mailbox with a perfect red lever pointed upwards.**Â 

**â€œWere you tailing me earlier?â€**Â 

**Clarissaâ€™s voice came out of nowhere, disembodied. I looked around me wildly, my unease ratcheting up several notches. A hand rested on my shoulder from behind; I wheeled around.**Â Â 

**â€œChill out, freak,â€ Clarissa laughed. She looked at the tree next to her, brushing off some twigs. â€œMy nest is up *there*.â€**Â 

**â€œYourâ€“nest?â€**Â 

**â€œItâ€™s a joke, heard of those before?â€**Â 

**I suddenly noticed she was wearing a yellow Walkman cassette player. We always BS that if we meet a chick with a portable cassette player, weâ€™ll automatically drop to one knee, no questions asked.**Â 

**â€œSo youâ€™re that much of a dork that you listen to cassette tapes in 2020?!â€**Â 

**â€œAnd youâ€™re telling me you donâ€™t have one on you right now?â€**

**Wordlessly, I raised my bandâ€™s cassette tape out of my pocket.**Â 

**â€œGive me that,â€ she laughed, snatching it out of my hand. â€œMaybe we *are* a match!â€**Â 

**I followed her inside.**Â 

**â€œMy roommates are out for the weekendâ€â€“glancing at the couchâ€“â€you can just shove all that shit over, sorry. We have beer, lemonade, soda...or maybe you like the harder stuff?â€**Â 

**I settled in and tried to relax, taking in what was around me. Nothing odd really. There was a crystal salt lamp whose warm glow looked afloat in the dim room. I could faintly sniff sage. A white cat met my gaze and darted out of sight, desperate to be forgotten.**Â 

**â€œYou donâ€™t get many visitâ€“â€**Â 

**The sentence was robbed from my throat. Clarissa was putting a glass of Jack Daniels on the table, naked beside the burgundy lingerie faintly interrupting her skin. I could see the thing in plain sightâ€“it was moving from side to side in a sort of carefree, feline attitude, *curling* back on itself this way and that, hairless and freckled as it tapered to its tip. It was a magnificent tail, too magnificent to be an accident. I closed my eyes and took a shot of the Jack.**Â 

**â€œI know what youâ€™re thinking,â€ Clarissa smiled. She sat down next to me, running her hand along my shoulder. â€œYouâ€™re thinking â€˜itâ€™s impossible, this canâ€™t actually be happening.â€™â€**Â 

**â€œYou must be psychic,â€ I shot back dryly.**Â 

**â€œYouâ€™re thinking,â€ she pressed on, â€œthat science eliminates the possibility of my existence.â€**

**I didnâ€™t say anything.**Â 

**â€œWhatâ€™s wrong, rock star, you donâ€™t want to play along? I know that you know it allâ€“how they say a human tail is only an abomination of the coccyx, a *vestige* of the behind that we all left behind...right?â€**

**â€œWhat are you getting at here, Clarissa?â€**Â 

**She took a swig of lemonade and rolled the juice around her mouth, her gaze unbroken.**Â 

**â€œNothing you havenâ€™t already thought of ten thousand times, but Iâ€™ll humor you. If the only reason humans donâ€™t have tails is because of some kind of disabled gene-signal, then the chances of more than one being on the planet is like one in billions. So if you realized there were *others like you*, that hypothesis would suddenly be on very thin ice.â€**Â 

**My blood ran cold. I leaned all the way back on the sofa until my eyes were looking at the ceiling. The clustered nerve-endings were firing off in tingles that made it hard for me to resist the urge to let it squirm beneath me. All of my practiced methods for controlling the thing were failing. It was as if it somehow sensed another of its kind and now had license to awaken. Sheâ€™d caught me by the tail.**Â 

**Clarissa leaned over me, her face close to mine. â€œShow it to me,â€ she whispered.**Â 

**No one had set eyes on it outside of my parents; I hadnâ€™t seen them since they put me up for adoption. I sat up, pulled the back of my shirt up and leaned over. Her eyes felt like hot embers across its naked surface. She lifted it between her fingers, held it in her palm, caressed it. I suddenly noticed how heavily I was breathing.**

**â€œThere are many of us, you know,â€ she said softly.**

**â€œHow many?â€**

**Clarissa paused. â€œI donâ€™t know, to be honest. But a lot. I met them in the genetic labs outside Salt Lake.â€**Â 

**â€œWait, geneticâ€“â€**

**â€œShhh!â€ She put a finger to my lips and straddled me, pulling my hands through her blue hair. â€œWeâ€™ll talk about it later.â€**Â 

**I clutched her swaying tail and let its smoothness run through my fingers.**Â 

**â€œWeâ€™re a match,â€ she giggled, â€œa match made in some dirty heaven.â€**Â 

**That evening, for the first time in my life, I surrendered fully to whatever it is that I am. Clarissa hasnâ€™t left my side since; weâ€™re in Cheyenne now. Thereâ€™s not a day that goes by where I donâ€™t think: Iâ€™ve never been happierâ€“or more deeply, inconsolably frightened.**Â

title: About the infinite possibilities of DAO
body:
DAO, the decentralized autonomous organization.  Different from the hierarchical structure of modern enterprises, the flat structure of DAO can maximize the rights and interests of ordinary participants.  The non-intermediary and completely open communication make the barriers to participation extremely low. At the same time, the direct collision of ideas makes the communication generate value, and it is put into practice through DAO Treasury.  All in all, DAO can make many people's dreams come true.  Below I will explore the infinite possibilities of DAO by analyzing the DAO architecture and several possible examples.

Relatively flat architecture (node-link)-an opportunity for ordinary people

The autonomous function of DAO is realized through governance, and due to its flat structure, each participant can obtain relatively fair participation and decision-making power.  Compared with the wear and tear of thinking caused by distinct levels in modern social organizations, DAO's node-like links can maximize the use of individual ideas.  In the web2 social system, the output productivity of ordinary people's ideas is extremely low, because it is insignificant in the eyes of bystanders and can be almost negligible, and ideas without attention will naturally be lost in the flood of information.  (Unless it is under the attention of the public) In DAO, because each individual is a participant in it, consensus exists directly, ideas directly collide, are gathered and transformed, and efficiency is greatly improved.  As a result, ordinary people can seek opportunities in it, because in DAO, Every Thought Counts. Every sentence of your speech can become productive.

No intermediary-Fuck algorithm

The essence of web2's social system is based on algorithms.  As we all know, algorithms can manipulate human cognition, just as information flow can indulge people and weaken their sensitivity to the content.  Therefore, DAO's non-intermediate open-content minimizes the intermediate impact.  After all, people should not be chosen by content.  Fuck algorithm.

Open-anyone welcome

As long as you have the most basic physiological functions, you can join a DAO.  The decentralized nature of the DAO itself determines that it can be open like any blockchain, but you donâ€™t have to remember complicated private keys or mnemonic words, and you donâ€™t have to worry about your copy of their books being damaged.  You need a discord and Feishu account, just remember their passwords, after all, ideas donâ€™t need to be carved into the blockchain.  (But if there is on-chain governance, it must be a wallet, but there are also many centralized wallet solutions)

Example-uploader

Generally speaking, video making is centralized.  But on DAO, everyone can edit, and small can provide ideas. In essence, it is a process of accumulating scattered productivity through DAO.

Instance-writer

Writing things is not practical for much collaboration, but besides the content, many derivatives are still worth discussing.  The organizational form of DAO allows output and reception to be at the same level, which reduces the loss and at the same time brings the heart closer to the heart, forming a benign development.

Summarize:

Since the types of DAOs are relatively abundant now, what we are talking about here should be attributed to social DAO, but the development of DAO in the future should tend to be Lego, similar to the current Defi.  However, the human level is essentially higher than the code, so the author is looking forward to how the ecology derived from DAO will affect the existing web2 ecology in the future.  Wait and see!

In her case, it was a win. She was wearing a black romper striped orange, yellow, green; her hair was blue and cut boyishly short. The obligatory septum piercing made her nose look like a jewelled accessory. Style, attitude, cuteness. Bad-ass but delicate. The interesting part: the picture wasnâ€™t a picture but actually a moving boomerang, one of those images perpetually repeating two seconds of movement.**

**The boomerang showed Clarissa from behind, jogging in-place on a sidewalk with her face looking coyly back into the camera. I donâ€™t need to mention the advantages such an angle affords those of the requisite affinitiesâ€“but there was something else. Something *else.* There looked to be a kind of independent movement beneath the fabric around her tailbone, like an appendage that was rising and falling as she ran. You could *just* make out the outline. It couldnâ€™t beâ€¦**

**I put my phone away and started pumping some beat-mixes to get my mind straight. Things couldnâ€™t be *that* freaky in Utah. My headphones werenâ€™t loud enough to block out the image. The thing that bothered me most was that my attraction to her hadnâ€™t waned; if anything, I felt *more* attracted. Had I been watching too many shapeshifter animes? That was probably the case regardless.**Â 

**Even so, there was no doubt that Clarissaâ€™s festive romper was hiding a full-grown tailâ€“like, none at all.Â  I watched the boomerang over and over again, turning my phone this way and that. There was no other conclusion. I considered calling my bandmates for brotherly support but in the end opted for privacy. Imagine if they heard I was seeing a girl with a *tail.* Literally a tail dangling down her rear. Her caption read: â€œWyoming-raised, Utah-grown. I donâ€™t want to go to Paris or Prague. Take me to a hidden place we can share secrets.â€ It was just too much.**Â 

**The first time I met Clarissa it was somewhere near State St. Itâ€™s hard for me to keep track of the roads because theyâ€™re all numbered on a grid based on their proximity to the Mormon temple. Clarissa told me that this system makes it easier to get around and not get lost. She laughed when I disagreed. We ate vegan wraps in one of those generic Salt Lake plazas made of Mexican eateries and Asian stores. Clarissa explained that she ate healthy when it suited her schedule and mood, which made her â€œa seasonal veganâ€. It was summertime in Salt Lake; she wore a dirty-green tank-top and gray denim shorts ripped across the thighs; her hair was bluer than Freddie Mercuryâ€™s stage lighting.**Â 

**She was one of those girls who was easy to talk to, but from whom you couldnâ€™t allow your attention to waver. Clarissa was no prolific talker. Instead I got a watchful loner vibe, someone youâ€™d see walking along deserted railroad tracks, someone who considered Bjork their private therapist. I kept imagining how I could bring the topic up without coming across as a total creep. â€œI didnâ€™t know people in Utah had tails...is that common here?â€ Gross. Maybe something more personal. â€œThat romper you had on does a lot for your tail.â€ God, no. I settled on: â€œCan you show me that running move from your profile?â€**Â 

**We were walking along the sidewalks in the glow of the street lamps; night had fallen on the strange city made of numbers. Clarissaâ€™s hand was clasped softly in mine. I kept resisting the temptation to look behind her like an idiot. She was pressing me with questions somewhat absently. When I told her my bandâ€™s name was Nineteeneightyfornicate, she lost it and started going through all of our pictures on Instagram. That name was Isaacâ€™s idea, not mine! It did have a nice ring to it.**Â 

**She stopped walking and turned on me suddenly.**

**â€œYou know, donâ€™t you?â€**

**â€œKnowâ€“know what?â€ I stammered lamely.**Â 

**â€œOh come off the bullshit, man. Youâ€™ve known this whole time.â€ Staring me frankly in the eyes, she took my hand and ran it along something long, firm, cylindrical on her backside. My heartbeat quickened and a soft moan emitted from my throat. Clarissa giggled and threw my hand away.**Â 

**â€œAny secrets youâ€™d like to share with me?â€**Â 

**I looked at her for a second, processing. â€œI already told you my dirty band nameâ€“â€**

**â€œRight,â€ she scoffed. â€œI hope you come up with something better by tomorrow.â€**

**She turned and began receding into the jasmine-bordered shadows. I realized that we had been surrounded by cats ever since we started walking. They now trailed her in unison like a row of ducklings down the sidewalk.**Â 

**â€œI DIDNâ€™T KNOW YOU WERE A CAT PERSON!â€ I yelled hopelessly.**Â 

**She laughed and raised a long middle finger into the air without turning around. I sighed and began walking in the other direction back to my hotel. I opened my phone to a new text message from Clarissa. It didnâ€™t say anything; sheâ€™d only sent three cat emojis with their tails in the air. I marveled at how little I knew what in the hell was going on. *I just stroked a human tail. That really happened.* And yet, perversely, I couldnâ€™t wait for the next day.**Â 

***....Any secrets youâ€™d like to share with meâ€¦***

**Iâ€™ll come cleanâ€“that night wasnâ€™t the first time I googled â€œhumans with tailsâ€. There had been drunken nights alone that I obsessed over the idea. My thoughts were ransacked by half-humanoids risen from primordial tetrapods, dripping with sea-foam and tails dragging in the sand. I told you I was a weird guy. To this point, the greatest harm all this had done was butcher my online algorithmsâ€“I would get ads for kinky Halloween costumes, which routinely raised some eyebrows.**Â 

***She could be a government spy on some troll-job,* I thought to myself. The idea tormented me for several hours. What was worse, I thought, the CIA using search history and store-bought accessories to play with my mind, or the possibility that I had met some kind of hybrid human with a rope of flesh swinging from her backside? The little bit of ganja I had left made my speculations thicker and more confusing. She had to be real. Why would the government waste time mind-fucking a guy from a band named Nineteeneightyfornicate? I went from that to wondering what she ate when she was stoned.**Â Â 

**Before I knew it, I was stepping out onto the curb in front of her house in my black knock-off Christian Diors. Who was this profane intruder in Provo? An agent *provo*cateur, I grinned to myself. I didnâ€™t know there could be neighborhoods with trees in the desert. Seemed like the Mormons were pretty good landscapers when they werenâ€™t busy granting all their wives eternal life. Who knew! Clarissa lived in a blue house with a quaint little front porch, one of those places that really has the picture-book mailbox with a perfect red lever pointed upwards.**Â 

**â€œWere you tailing me earlier?â€**Â 

**Clarissaâ€™s voice came out of nowhere, disembodied. I looked around me wildly, my unease ratcheting up several notches. A hand rested on my shoulder from behind; I wheeled around.**Â Â 

**â€œChill out, freak,â€ Clarissa laughed. She looked at the tree next to her, brushing off some twigs. â€œMy nest is up *there*.â€**Â 

**â€œYourâ€“nest?â€**Â 

**â€œItâ€™s a joke, heard of those before?â€**Â 

**I suddenly noticed she was wearing a yellow Walkman cassette player. We always BS that if we meet a chick with a portable cassette player, weâ€™ll automatically drop to one knee, no questions asked.**Â 

**â€œSo youâ€™re that much of a dork that you listen to cassette tapes in 2020?!â€**Â 

**â€œAnd youâ€™re telling me you donâ€™t have one on you right now?â€**

**Wordlessly, I raised my bandâ€™s cassette tape out of my pocket.**Â 

**â€œGive me that,â€ she laughed, snatching it out of my hand. â€œMaybe we *are* a match!â€**Â 

**I followed her inside.**Â 

**â€œMy roommates are out for the weekendâ€â€“glancing at the couchâ€“â€you can just shove all that shit over, sorry. We have beer, lemonade, soda...or maybe you like the harder stuff?â€**Â 

**I settled in and tried to relax, taking in what was around me. Nothing odd really. There was a crystal salt lamp whose warm glow looked afloat in the dim room. I could faintly sniff sage. A white cat met my gaze and darted out of sight, desperate to be forgotten.**Â 

**â€œYou donâ€™t get many visitâ€“â€**Â 

**The sentence was robbed from my throat. Clarissa was putting a glass of Jack Daniels on the table, naked beside the burgundy lingerie faintly interrupting her skin. I could see the thing in plain sightâ€“it was moving from side to side in a sort of carefree, feline attitude, *curling* back on itself this way and that, hairless and freckled as it tapered to its tip. It was a magnificent tail, too magnificent to be an accident. I closed my eyes and took a shot of the Jack.**Â 

**â€œI know what youâ€™re thinking,â€ Clarissa smiled. She sat down next to me, running her hand along my shoulder. â€œYouâ€™re thinking â€˜itâ€™s impossible, this canâ€™t actually be happening.â€™â€**Â 

**â€œYou must be psychic,â€ I shot back dryly.**Â 

**â€œYouâ€™re thinking,â€ she pressed on, â€œthat science eliminates the possibility of my existence.â€**

**I didnâ€™t say anything.**Â 

**â€œWhatâ€™s wrong, rock star, you donâ€™t want to play along? I know that you know it allâ€“how they say a human tail is only an abomination of the coccyx, a *vestige* of the behind that we all left behind...right?â€**

**â€œWhat are you getting at here, Clarissa?â€**Â 

**She took a swig of lemonade and rolled the juice around her mouth, her gaze unbroken.**Â 

**â€œNothing you havenâ€™t already thought of ten thousand times, but Iâ€™ll humor you. If the only reason humans donâ€™t have tails is because of some kind of disabled gene-signal, then the chances of more than one being on the planet is like one in billions. So if you realized there were *others like you*, that hypothesis would suddenly be on very thin ice.â€**Â 

**My blood ran cold. I leaned all the way back on the sofa until my eyes were looking at the ceiling. The clustered nerve-endings were firing off in tingles that made it hard for me to resist the urge to let it squirm beneath me. All of my practiced methods for controlling the thing were failing. It was as if it somehow sensed another of its kind and now had license to awaken. Sheâ€™d caught me by the tail.**Â 

**Clarissa leaned over me, her face close to mine. â€œShow it to me,â€ she whispered.**Â 

**No one had set eyes on it outside of my parents; I hadnâ€™t seen them since they put me up for adoption. I sat up, pulled the back of my shirt up and leaned over. Her eyes felt like hot embers across its naked surface. She lifted it between her fingers, held it in her palm, caressed it. I suddenly noticed how heavily I was breathing.**

**â€œThere are many of us, you know,â€ she said softly.**

**â€œHow many?â€**

**Clarissa paused. â€œI donâ€™t know, to be honest. But a lot. I met them in the genetic labs outside Salt Lake.â€**Â 

**â€œWait, geneticâ€“â€**

**â€œShhh!â€ She put a finger to my lips and straddled me, pulling my hands through her blue hair. â€œWeâ€™ll talk about it later.â€**Â 

**I clutched her swaying tail and let its smoothness run through my fingers.**Â 

**â€œWeâ€™re a match,â€ she giggled, â€œa match made in some dirty heaven.â€**Â 

**That evening, for the first time in my life, I surrendered fully to whatever it is that I am. Clarissa hasnâ€™t left my side since; weâ€™re in Cheyenne now. Thereâ€™s not a day that goes by where I donâ€™t think: Iâ€™ve never been happierâ€“or more deeply, inconsolably frightened.**Â

Married to Changgan, Shatou waits for the demeanor.
In May, the south wind is booming, Sijunâ€™s chin is mausoleum.
In August, the west wind blows up, so I want to promote my son.
How to grieve, see less and see more parting.
When Xiangtan arrived in a few days, the concubine's dream became more and more turbulent.
Last night, the violent demeanor broke the Jiangtou tree.
Miaomiao is dark, where are the pedestrians.

The mandarin ducks are on the green pu, and the emerald is in the brocade.

body:
**I think it hit me at some point during the Uber ride to her house: this could be the most important hook-up in human history. And the scariest. I know it sounds stupid and indulgent to say that, especially coming from another hetero-normative dude in black Christian Diors like me. (Whatever, they were knock-offs.) But given the extraordinary features of this interaction, along with its consequences for how people think of themselves, I really donâ€™t think itâ€™s an exaggeration. All of this is true by the way. I donâ€™t have the time to make any of this up, and frankly I sucked pretty bad in Language Arts. My grade-school teachers will bug out if they read this.**

**My band was doing a show in Salt Lake Cityâ€“you know, Mormon utopia in the middle of the desert. Our next gig in Boise had been cancelled for reasons we didnâ€™t entirely understand. When youâ€™re on the road you just kind of run with things, I guess. We decided to hang out in Utah for a couple of days. Somebody said we could â€œbackpack in the watercolor meadows of the Uintahsâ€. Sounded like a good time. title: 1SWIPEAWAY
body:
**I think it hit me at some point during the Uber ride to her house: this could be the most important hook-up in human history. And the scariest. I know it sounds stupid and indulgent to say that, especially coming from another hetero-normative dude in black Christian Diors like me. (Whatever, they were knock-offs.) But given the extraordinary features of this interaction, along with its consequences for how people think of themselves, I really donâ€™t think itâ€™s an exaggeration. All of this is true by the way. I donâ€™t have the time to make any of this up, and frankly I sucked pretty bad in Language Arts. My grade-school teachers will bug out if they read this.**

**My band was doing a show in Salt Lake Cityâ€“you know, Mormon utopia in the middle of the desert. Our next gig in Boise had been cancelled for reasons we didnâ€™t entirely understand. When youâ€™re on the road you just kind of run with things, I guess. We decided to hang out in Utah for a couple of days. Somebody said we could â€œbackpack in the watercolor meadows of the Uintahsâ€. Sounded like a good time. We do retrowave electronica stuff, lots of synthy sounds with flashing lights and voice effects. Everyoneâ€™s into the eighties again, even the Mormons it turns out.**

**I still donâ€™t think of myself as a hook-up guy, even after all these years on the road. Iâ€™m serious. Itâ€™s not something I enjoy or even particularly like. I see hook-ups as one of the rites of being a traveling musician, or maybe even a curse. Itâ€™s like how prime ministers have to shake hands with people they donâ€™t necessarily like. Iâ€™m a reluctant diplomat of the grunge scene. Everything that guys like David Bowie did make total sense to me. They turned their lives upside-down just to try and find something real. I wonder if they ever found itâ€“when I did, it scared the crap out of me.**

**The first Tinder girl I met in Utah was one of those â€œitâ€™s for a good causeâ€-type chicks. Iâ€™m not trying to offend anybody, itâ€™s just the only way I can think to describe her. What annoys me about those girls is that they all have the same personality. Theyâ€™re almost breathless to prove how angry they are about all the *right* things. It makes me feel like everything I know is wrong or something. You just sit there and listen and drown in their syndicated outrage. I swiped right for shallow reasons, yes. The messed-up thing is that I anticipated my annoyance as I glanced at her pics. I was shamelessly undeterred.**

**Her peach spaghetti-strap top swallowed most of my attention, even as she soliloquized about non binary love and dying pandas. (OK, I made that last one up.) Her blonde hair was pulled back in a ponytail. It was less a conversation and more a kind of reciting on her partâ€“anyone couldâ€™ve been sitting in front of her. I wonder if she wouldâ€™ve acted differently if she knew who I was. A few hours later, I finished softly somewhere in the bobbing bramble of hair in my lap. It was depressing. She fixed her ponytail in the mirror, checked her phone, then quickly left.**

**I donâ€™t usually let people get to know me too well, not even my bandmates. I mean we drop acid together sometimes, bro-bonding stuff, that kind of thing. Thatâ€™s about it. Even with girls, Iâ€™m a sex-in-the-dark kind of dude. They probably think Iâ€™m weird but I never ask. When the peach-top pedant was leaving I gave her one of our albums on cassette tape. It was awkward (â€œUh, thanksâ€¦?â€) but I feel like itâ€™s the best I can do.**

**Somewhere in the discussion of her saintly works, she had mentioned something her uncle had seen in a mall near downtown Salt Lake City. It was like an upright human with amphibian skin or something. Her uncle was a janitor who cleaned floors there late at night. The thing had come out of a basement stairwell, looked at him for a moment, then turned right back around and disappeared. The really crazy thing was that her uncle said he felt some kind of emotion deep in his chest that he never felt before, sort of like how you feel when you lock eyes with a stranger that looks inexplicably familiar. She reported all of this as a joke, rattling it off at blinding speed in her machine-gun dialogue of goodspeak. I couldnâ€™t stop thinking about it for the rest of the night, though, even when we started making out.**

**The guys in our band like to joke about the golden thumbâ€“itâ€™s when you start a streak of matching with the cityâ€™s hottest women. Thatâ€™s millennial serendipity at its finest. Isaac had the golden thumb in Topeka and we didnâ€™t see him until Michigan, but in Michigan the algorithms failed him. It works in mysterious ways. When I matched with this Clarissa girl from Provo, I decided Salt Lake City *was* a promised land, or at least my own Topeka. I had no idea what I was getting myself into, nor has that condition of not-knowing changed. But let me back up...**

**Clarissa was one of those one-pic profiles, which is risky. Youâ€™re betting that this single picture is so alluring that the opposite swiper needs no further proof of your hotness. In her case, it was a win. She was wearing a black romper striped orange, yellow, green; her hair was blue and cut boyishly short. The obligatory septum piercing made her nose look like a jewelled accessory. Style, attitude, cuteness. Bad-ass but delicate. The interesting part: the picture wasnâ€™t a picture but actually a moving boomerang, one of those images perpetually repeating two seconds of movement.**

**The boomerang showed Clarissa from behind, jogging in-place on a sidewalk with her face looking coyly back into the camera. I donâ€™t need to mention the advantages such an angle affords those of the requisite affinitiesâ€“but there was something else. Something *else.* There looked to be a kind of independent movement beneath the fabric around her tailbone, like an appendage that was rising and falling as she ran. You could *just* make out the outline. It couldnâ€™t beâ€¦**

**I put my phone away and started pumping some beat-mixes to get my mind straight. Things couldnâ€™t be *that* freaky in Utah. My headphones werenâ€™t loud enough to block out the image. The thing that bothered me most was that my attraction to her hadnâ€™t waned; if anything, I felt *more* attracted. Had I been watching too many shapeshifter animes? That was probably the case regardless.**

**Even so, there was no doubt that Clarissaâ€™s festive romper was hiding a full-grown tailâ€“like, none at all.Â  I watched the boomerang over and over again, turning my phone this way and that. There was no other conclusion. I considered calling my bandmates for brotherly support but in the end opted for privacy. Imagine if they heard I was seeing a girl with a *tail.* Literally a tail dangling down her rear. Her caption read: â€œWyoming-raised, Utah-grown. I donâ€™t want to go to Paris or Prague. Take me to a hidden place we can share secrets.â€ It was just too much.**

**The first time I met Clarissa it was somewhere near State St. Itâ€™s hard for me to keep track of the roads because theyâ€™re all numbered on a grid based on their proximity to the Mormon temple. Clarissa told me that this system makes it easier to get around and not get lost. She laughed when I disagreed. We ate vegan wraps in one of those generic Salt Lake plazas made of Mexican eateries and Asian stores. Clarissa explained that she ate healthy when it suited her schedule and mood, which made her â€œa seasonal veganâ€. It was summertime in Salt Lake; she wore a dirty-green tank-top and gray denim shorts ripped across the thighs; her hair was bluer than Freddie Mercuryâ€™s stage lighting.**

**She was one of those girls who was easy to talk to, but from whom you couldnâ€™t allow your attention to waver. Clarissa was no prolific talker. Instead I got a watchful loner vibe, someone youâ€™d see walking along deserted railroad tracks, someone who considered Bjork their private therapist. I kept imagining how I could bring the topic up without coming across as a total creep. â€œI didnâ€™t know people in Utah had tails...is that common here?â€ Gross. Maybe something more personal. â€œThat romper you had on does a lot for your tail.â€ God, no. I settled on: â€œCan you show me that running move from your profile?â€**

**We were walking along the sidewalks in the glow of the street lamps; night had fallen on the strange city made of numbers. Clarissaâ€™s hand was clasped softly in mine. I kept resisting the temptation to look behind her like an idiot. She was pressing me with questions somewhat absently. When I told her my bandâ€™s name was Nineteeneightyfornicate, she lost it and started going through all of our pictures on Instagram. That name was Isaacâ€™s idea, not mine! It did have a nice ring to it.**

**She stopped walking and turned on me suddenly.**

**â€œYou know, donâ€™t you?â€**

**â€œKnowâ€“know what?â€ I stammered lamely.**

**â€œOh come off the bullshit, man. Youâ€™ve known this whole time.â€ Staring me frankly in the eyes, she took my hand and ran it along something long, firm, cylindrical on her backside. My heartbeat quickened and a soft moan emitted from my throat. Clarissa giggled and threw my hand away.**

**â€œAny secrets youâ€™d like to share with me?â€**

**I looked at her for a second, processing. â€œI already told you my dirty band nameâ€“â€**

**â€œRight,â€ she scoffed. â€œI hope you come up with something better by tomorrow.â€**

**She turned and began receding into the jasmine-bordered shadows. I realized that we had been surrounded by cats ever since we started walking. They now trailed her in unison like a row of ducklings down the sidewalk.**

**â€œI DIDNâ€™T KNOW YOU WERE A CAT PERSON!â€ I yelled hopelessly.**

**She laughed and raised a long middle finger into the air without turning around. I sighed and began walking in the other direction back to my hotel. I opened my phone to a new text message from Clarissa. It didnâ€™t say anything; sheâ€™d only sent three cat emojis with their tails in the air. I marveled at how little I knew what in the hell was going on. *I just stroked a human tail. That really happened.* And yet, perversely, I couldnâ€™t wait for the next day.**

***....Any secrets youâ€™d like to share with meâ€¦***

**Iâ€™ll come cleanâ€“that night wasnâ€™t the first time I googled â€œhumans with tailsâ€. There had been drunken nights alone that I obsessed over the idea. My thoughts were ransacked by half-humanoids risen from primordial tetrapods, dripping with sea-foam and tails dragging in the sand. I told you I was a weird guy. To this point, the greatest harm all this had done was butcher my online algorithmsâ€“I would get ads for kinky Halloween costumes, which routinely raised some eyebrows.**

***She could be a government spy on some troll-job,* I thought to myself. The idea tormented me for several hours. What was worse, I thought, the CIA using search history and store-bought accessories to play with my mind, or the possibility that I had met some kind of hybrid human with a rope of flesh swinging from her backside? The little bit of ganja I had left made my speculations thicker and more confusing. She had to be real. Why would the government waste time mind-fucking a guy from a band named Nineteeneightyfornicate? I went from that to wondering what she ate when she was stoned.**

**Before I knew it, I was stepping out onto the curb in front of her house in my black knock-off Christian Diors. Who was this profane intruder in Provo? An agent *provo*cateur, I grinned to myself. I didnâ€™t know there could be neighborhoods with trees in the desert. Seemed like the Mormons were pretty good landscapers when they werenâ€™t busy granting all their wives eternal life. Who knew! Clarissa lived in a blue house with a quaint little front porch, one of those places that really has the picture-book mailbox with a perfect red lever pointed upwards.**

**â€œWere you tailing me earlier?â€**

**Clarissaâ€™s voice came out of nowhere, disembodied. I looked around me wildly, my unease ratcheting up several notches. A hand rested on my shoulder from behind; I wheeled around.**

**â€œChill out, freak,â€ Clarissa laughed. She looked at the tree next to her, brushing off some twigs. â€œMy nest is up *there*.â€**

**â€œYourâ€“nest?â€**

**â€œItâ€™s a joke, heard of those before?â€**

**I suddenly noticed she was wearing a yellow Walkman cassette player. We always BS that if we meet a chick with a portable cassette player, weâ€™ll automatically drop to one knee, no questions asked.**

**â€œSo youâ€™re that much of a dork that you listen to cassette tapes in 2020?!â€**

**â€œAnd youâ€™re telling me you donâ€™t have one on you right now?â€**

**Wordlessly, I raised my bandâ€™s cassette tape out of my pocket.**

**â€œGive me that,â€ she laughed, snatching it out of my hand. â€œMaybe we *are* a match!â€**

**I followed her inside.**

**â€œMy roommates are out for the weekendâ€â€“glancing at the couchâ€“â€you can just shove all that shit over, sorry. We have beer, lemonade, soda...or maybe you like the harder stuff?â€**

**I settled in and tried to relax, taking in what was around me. Nothing odd really. There was a crystal salt lamp whose warm glow looked afloat in the dim room. I could faintly sniff sage. A white cat met my gaze and darted out of sight, desperate to be forgotten.**

**â€œYou donâ€™t get many visitâ€“â€**

**The sentence was robbed from my throat. Clarissa was putting a glass of Jack Daniels on the table, naked beside the burgundy lingerie faintly interrupting her skin. I could see the thing in plain sightâ€“it was moving from side to side in a sort of carefree, feline attitude, *curling* back on itself this way and that, hairless and freckled as it tapered to its tip. It was a magnificent tail, too magnificent to be an accident. I closed my eyes and took a shot of the Jack.**

**â€œI know what youâ€™re thinking,â€ Clarissa smiled. She sat down next to me, running her hand along my shoulder. â€œYouâ€™re thinking â€˜itâ€™s impossible, this canâ€™t actually be happening.â€™â€**

**â€œYou must be psychic,â€ I shot back dryly.**

**â€œYouâ€™re thinking,â€ she pressed on, â€œthat science eliminates the possibility of my existence.â€**

**I didnâ€™t say anything.**

**â€œWhatâ€™s wrong, rock star, you donâ€™t want to play along? I know that you know it allâ€“how they say a human tail is only an abomination of the coccyx, a *vestige* of the behind that we all left behind...right?â€**

**â€œWhat are you getting at here, Clarissa?â€**

**She took a swig of lemonade and rolled the juice around her mouth, her gaze unbroken.**

**â€œNothing you havenâ€™t already thought of ten thousand times, but Iâ€™ll humor you. If the only reason humans donâ€™t have tails is because of some kind of disabled gene-signal, then the chances of more than one being on the planet is like one in billions. So if you realized there were *others like you*, that hypothesis would suddenly be on very thin ice.â€**

**My blood ran cold. I leaned all the way back on the sofa until my eyes were looking at the ceiling. The clustered nerve-endings were firing off in tingles that made it hard for me to resist the urge to let it squirm beneath me. All of my practiced methods for controlling the thing were failing. It was as if it somehow sensed another of its kind and now had license to awaken. Sheâ€™d caught me by the tail.**

**Clarissa leaned over me, her face close to mine. â€œShow it to me,â€ she whispered.**

**No one had set eyes on it outside of my parents; I hadnâ€™t seen them since they put me up for adoption. I sat up, pulled the back of my shirt up and leaned over. Her eyes felt like hot embers across its naked surface. She lifted it between her fingers, held it in her palm, caressed it. I suddenly noticed how heavily I was breathing.**

**â€œThere are many of us, you know,â€ she said softly.**

**â€œHow many?â€**

**Clarissa paused. â€œI donâ€™t know, to be honest. But a lot. I met them in the genetic labs outside Salt Lake.â€**

**â€œWait, geneticâ€“â€**

**â€œShhh!â€ She put a finger to my lips and straddled me, pulling my hands through her blue hair. â€œWeâ€™ll talk about it later.â€**

**I clutched her swaying tail and let its smoothness run through my fingers.**

**â€œWeâ€™re a match,â€ she giggled, â€œa match made in some dirty heaven.â€**

**That evening, for the first time in my life, I surrendered fully to whatever it is that I am. Clarissa hasnâ€™t left my side since; weâ€™re in Cheyenne now. Thereâ€™s not a day that goes by where I donâ€™t think: Iâ€™ve never been happierâ€“or more deeply, inconsolably frightened.**

title: How do you select outstanding talents?  How do you judge if they fit into Berkshire's culture?
body:
A: Although there are many talents, it is not easy to select the right ones for our company.Â Â I know a guy who can beat the S&P, but this guy, I can't marry my daughter to anyone. Â 

Â 

So, the first basic rule is, I have to choose people that I recognize, people that I want to be with, people that I can be friends with, people that I can be family with. Â 

Â 

Such a person, since can get my recognition, on the body must have the advantages I admire, and I have the same pursuit. Â 

Â 

People like that, even better than me, are people I want to emulate. Â 

Â 

Such people, I admire their behavior and wisdom, I appreciate their impeccable character, especially hope to make friends with them. Â 

Â 

I give them one thing to do, they can do ten of them, and they always do better than I expected.Â Â Make sure you pick the best. Â

title: How do you define success?  Has your definition of success changed over the years you've been investing?
body:
A: There is an old saying that success is the fulfillment of the pursuit of satisfaction, happiness is the treasure of contentment.Â Â Success is about getting what you want, while happiness is about wanting what you get. Â 

Â 

When I was younger, I always pursued financial independence.Â Â I want to work for myself, for people I respect.Â Â I want to be in control of the decision-making process. Â 

Â 

By the time I was 25, I was making enough to live on.Â Â At the time, I had two children, and I had about $2 million in today's money.Â Â After that, no matter how much money I made, IT was more than I could use. Â 

Â 

As you work your way through life, I hope you carry a scoreboard in your mind to measure your satisfaction with your performance and accomplishments.Â Â Don't worry too much about what the world around you thinks of your accomplishments. Instead, focus on what you think you did. Â 

Â 

When it comes to investment returns, my personal success is secondary. Berkshire's success always comes first.Â Â Just remember, always try to be a good person. Â

title: What do good investors have in common?
body:
A: One is to stick to your investment philosophy and the other is not to be swayed by emotional fluctuations.Â Â Good investors start with data. They enjoy investing. Â 

Â 

The people who invest well are the ones who really enjoy investing.Â Â They see investing as a game, and investing is the game they love. Â 

Â 

A good investor wants to be right first and make money second. Make the right decisions and the money will follow. Â 

Â 

Invest with tenacity.Â Â In the face of temptation, in the face of other people's interference, can you still adhere to their beliefs?Â Â I've seen too many smart people do stupid things because they follow the crowd. Â 

Â 

Also, good investors look to the future and don't dwell on past successes or failures. Â 

Â 

You may wish to read history and see how many tragic events have taken place in history.Â Â We were in World War II and we fought in the Civil War.Â Â America must do it! Â

title: When you were young, you could sit on a bench and think and form your own thoughts.
body:
The main reason why we are so successful today is that we spend a lot of time thinking.Â Â Berkshire holds no meetings, no committees. Â 

Â 

I don't know of a better way to become a more sane person than to sit down and read.Â Â Charlie and I spend most of our day reading. Â 

Â 

Students of efficient-market theory are at a disadvantage, and investors who find value through constant reading are at a big advantage. Â 

Â 

From my personal point of view, I have an advantage over others who are always holding their phones and don't know how to read and think.Â Â While others were Posting about what they had for breakfast, I read a few annual reports and gained some knowledge. Â 

Â 

I've seen a lot of changes in my time, especially in the way people spend their time. Â 

Â 

The chance of gold falling from the sky is about six times in a lifetime Â

title: How to seize contrarian investment opportunities?  In addition, how do you view risk?
body:
A: We have developed some filters at Berkshire based on years of experience.Â Â When I'm learning about or researching an investment opportunity, as long as there's one filter that checks it out, I definitely don't invest.Â Â Charlie has a similar filter. Â 

Â 

We don't try to understand a lot of things, we just need to understand a few things, and that is within our circle of competence. Â 

Â 

For example, you visited Nebraska Furniture Mart this morning, and when Berkshire bought the company, its founder, Mrs. B, chose cash over stock because she didn't think she understood stocks. Â 

Â 

It's important to know what you're capable of.Â Â Five years from now, I don't know which company will be no. 1 in auto manufacturing, so I'm not going to pick auto stocks.Â Â I prefer to do simple things within my own circle of competence. Â 

Â 

Good decisions scream at you.Â Â In 2008, for example, asset prices were cheap, so there was nothing to fear.Â Â Over the course of your investment career, you will come across this kind of golden opportunity about six times. Â 

Â 

Speaking of risk, in Berkshire's history, we've had one 2% loss and two 1% losses in our portfolio, both in 1974 and 1975, when we sold cheap assets and bought cheaper ones. Â 

Â 

Investing in stocks, if held for the long term, is risk-free, saving purchasing power now for the future.Â Â Cash is the risky asset. Â 

Â 

Financial theory uses beta as a measure of risk, but volatility is not risk, but loss of purchasing power is risk.Â Â The longer you stretch out, the weaker the fluctuations are. Â 

Â 

The risk of investing comes from the person making the investment.Â Â In our forthcoming annual report, I will discuss how to rethink risk.Â Â It is generally believed that stocks are riskier than bonds, but in the long run, this is not true. Â

title: What are some questions investors should be asking when evaluating a company, but often ignore?
body:
A: To start, look at seven or eight companies in one industry. Talk to management at each company and ask them general research questions. Â 

Â 

Also, ask the management of each company which competitor they would choose to invest their own money in and not move for 10 years.Â Â Then ask them which competitors they choose to short. Â 

Â 

Ask these two questions, and you probably know more about the industry than any veteran. Â 

Â 

The same goes for personal ascension, and it is recommended that you use this approach to examine those around you.Â Â Among your friends, who is your role model and who is your negative example? Â 

Â 

Think of it this way: which friend do you want to buy and own 10% of the future income, and which friend do you want to short.Â Â Think about the strengths of your role model and make them your own.Â Â Negative teaching material body what shortcomings, in their own body to abandon. Â 

Â 

You're all young people here, and you still have a chance to break bad habits.Â Â "The chains of habit, too light to be noticed at first, are too heavy to be broken."Â Â (The chains of habit are too light to be felt until they are too heavy to be broken.) Â 

Â 

Q8: What information do you need to know to value a company? Â 

Â 

A: To know A company well, you have to know its industry.Â Â Only invest in companies and industries that you understand, and don't leave your circle of competence. Â 

Â 

You need to know where the company has a competitive advantage over its peers, whether its management is good, and most importantly, whether it has a moat.Â Â Don't invest if you don't know how many competitors a company has. Â 

Â 

The moat of Coca-Cola is that coke has no taste memory and never gets tired of drinking. The moat of Railway is that the industry is saturated and no one can build new railways.Â Â So, coke, railway, these two industries, I now invest. Â

title: Magic
body: # The Magic Words are Squeamish Ossifrage

title: 1SWIPEAWAY
body:
**I think it hit me at some point during the Uber ride to her house: this could be the most important hook-up in human history. And the scariest. I know it sounds stupid and indulgent to say that, especially coming from another hetero-normative dude in black Christian Diors like me. (Whatever, they were knock-offs.) But given the extraordinary features of this interaction, along with its consequences for how people think of themselves, I really donâ€™t think itâ€™s an exaggeration. All of this is true by the way. I donâ€™t have the time to make any of this up, and frankly I sucked pretty bad in Language Arts. My grade-school teachers will bug out if they read this.**

**My band was doing a show in Salt Lake Cityâ€“you know, Mormon utopia in the middle of the desert. Our next gig in Boise had been cancelled for reasons we didnâ€™t entirely understand. When youâ€™re on the road you just kind of run with things, I guess. We decided to hang out in Utah for a couple of days. Somebody said we could â€œbackpack in the watercolor meadows of the Uintahsâ€. Sounded like a good time. We do retrowave electronica stuff, lots of synthy sounds with flashing lights and voice effects. Everyoneâ€™s into the eighties again, even the Mormons it turns out.**

**I still donâ€™t think of myself as a hook-up guy, even after all these years on the road. Iâ€™m serious. Itâ€™s not something I enjoy or even particularly like. I see hook-ups as one of the rites of being a traveling musician, or maybe even a curse. Itâ€™s like how prime ministers have to shake hands with people they donâ€™t necessarily like. Iâ€™m a reluctant diplomat of the grunge scene. Everything that guys like David Bowie did make total sense to me. They turned their lives upside-down just to try and find something real. I wonder if they ever found itâ€“when I did, it scared the crap out of me.**

**The first Tinder girl I met in Utah was one of those â€œitâ€™s for a good causeâ€-type chicks. Iâ€™m not trying to offend anybody, itâ€™s just the only way I can think to describe her. What annoys me about those girls is that they all have the same personality. Theyâ€™re almost breathless to prove how angry they are about all the *right* things. It makes me feel like everything I know is wrong or something. You just sit there and listen and drown in their syndicated outrage. I swiped right for shallow reasons, yes. The messed-up thing is that I anticipated my annoyance as I glanced at her pics. I was shamelessly undeterred.**

**Her peach spaghetti-strap top swallowed most of my attention, even as she soliloquized about non binary love and dying pandas. (OK, I made that last one up.) Her blonde hair was pulled back in a ponytail. It was less a conversation and more a kind of reciting on her partâ€“anyone couldâ€™ve been sitting in front of her. I wonder if she wouldâ€™ve acted differently if she knew who I was. A few hours later, I finished softly somewhere in the bobbing bramble of hair in my lap. It was depressing. She fixed her ponytail in the mirror, checked her phone, then quickly left.**

**I donâ€™t usually let people get to know me too well, not even my bandmates. I mean we drop acid together sometimes, bro-bonding stuff, that kind of thing. Thatâ€™s about it. Even with girls, Iâ€™m a sex-in-the-dark kind of dude. They probably think Iâ€™m weird but I never ask. When the peach-top pedant was leaving I gave her one of our albums on cassette tape. It was awkward (â€œUh, thanksâ€¦?â€) but I feel like itâ€™s the best I can do.**

**Somewhere in the discussion of her saintly works, she had mentioned something her uncle had seen in a mall near downtown Salt Lake City. It was like an upright human with amphibian skin or something. Her uncle was a janitor who cleaned floors there late at night. The thing had come out of a basement stairwell, looked at him for a moment, then turned right back around and disappeared. The really crazy thing was that her uncle said he felt some kind of emotion deep in his chest that he never felt before, sort of like how you feel when you lock eyes with a stranger that looks inexplicably familiar. She reported all of this as a joke, rattling it off at blinding speed in her machine-gun dialogue of goodspeak. I couldnâ€™t stop thinking about it for the rest of the night, though, even when we started making out.**

**The guys in our band like to joke about the golden thumbâ€“itâ€™s when you start a streak of matching with the cityâ€™s hottest women. Thatâ€™s millennial serendipity at its finest. Isaac had the golden thumb in Topeka and we didnâ€™t see him until Michigan, but in Michigan the algorithms failed him. It works in mysterious ways. When I matched with this Clarissa girl from Provo, I decided Salt Lake City *was* a promised land, or at least my own Topeka. I had no idea what I was getting myself into, nor has that condition of not-knowing changed. But let me back up...**

**Clarissa was one of those one-pic profiles, which is risky. Youâ€™re betting that this single picture is so alluring that the opposite swiper needs no further proof of your hotness. In her case, it was a win. She was wearing a black romper striped orange, yellow, green; her hair was blue and cut boyishly short. The obligatory septum piercing made her nose look like a jewelled accessory. Style, attitude, cuteness. Bad-ass but delicate. The interesting part: the picture wasnâ€™t a picture but actually a moving boomerang, one of those images perpetually repeating two seconds of movement.**

**The boomerang showed Clarissa from behind, jogging in-place on a sidewalk with her face looking coyly back into the camera. I donâ€™t need to mention the advantages such an angle affords those of the requisite affinitiesâ€“but there was something else. Something *else.* There looked to be a kind of independent movement beneath the fabric around her tailbone, like an appendage that was rising and falling as she ran. You could *just* make out the outline. It couldnâ€™t beâ€¦**

**I put my phone away and started pumping some beat-mixes to get my mind straight. Things couldnâ€™t be *that* freaky in Utah. My headphones werenâ€™t loud enough to block out the image. The thing that bothered me most was that my attraction to her hadnâ€™t waned; if anything, I felt *more* attracted. Had I been watching too many shapeshifter animes? That was probably the case regardless.**

**Even so, there was no doubt that Clarissaâ€™s festive romper was hiding a full-grown tailâ€“like, none at all.Â  I watched the boomerang over and over again, turning my phone this way and that. There was no other conclusion. I considered calling my bandmates for brotherly support but in the end opted for privacy. Imagine if they heard I was seeing a girl with a *tail.* Literally a tail dangling down her rear. Her caption read: â€œWyoming-raised, Utah-grown. I donâ€™t want to go to Paris or Prague. Take me to a hidden place we can share secrets.â€ It was just too much.**

**The first time I met Clarissa it was somewhere near State St. Itâ€™s hard for me to keep track of the roads because theyâ€™re all numbered on a grid based on their proximity to the Mormon temple. Clarissa told me that this system makes it easier to get around and not get lost. She laughed when I disagreed. We ate vegan wraps in one of those generic Salt Lake plazas made of Mexican eateries and Asian stores. Clarissa explained that she ate healthy when it suited her schedule and mood, which made her â€œa seasonal veganâ€. It was summertime in Salt Lake; she wore a dirty-green tank-top and gray denim shorts ripped across the thighs; her hair was bluer than Freddie Mercuryâ€™s stage lighting.**

**She was one of those girls who was easy to talk to, but from whom you couldnâ€™t allow your attention to waver. Clarissa was no prolific talker. Instead I got a watchful loner vibe, someone youâ€™d see walking along deserted railroad tracks, someone who considered Bjork their private therapist. I kept imagining how I could bring the topic up without coming across as a total creep. â€œI didnâ€™t know people in Utah had tails...is that common here?â€ Gross. Maybe something more personal. â€œThat romper you had on does a lot for your tail.â€ God, no. I settled on: â€œCan you show me that running move from your profile?â€**

**We were walking along the sidewalks in the glow of the street lamps; night had fallen on the strange city made of numbers. Clarissaâ€™s hand was clasped softly in mine. I kept resisting the temptation to look behind her like an idiot. She was pressing me with questions somewhat absently. When I told her my bandâ€™s name was Nineteeneightyfornicate, she lost it and started going through all of our pictures on Instagram. That name was Isaacâ€™s idea, not mine! It did have a nice ring to it.**

**She stopped walking and turned on me suddenly.**

**â€œYou know, donâ€™t you?â€**

**â€œKnowâ€“know what?â€ I stammered lamely.**

**â€œOh come off the bullshit, man. Youâ€™ve known this whole time.â€ Staring me frankly in the eyes, she took my hand and ran it along something long, firm, cylindrical on her backside. My heartbeat quickened and a soft moan emitted from my throat. Clarissa giggled and threw my hand away.**

**â€œAny secrets youâ€™d like to share with me?â€**

**I looked at her for a second, processing. â€œI already told you my dirty band nameâ€“â€**

**â€œRight,â€ she scoffed. â€œI hope you come up with something better by tomorrow.â€**

**She turned and began receding into the jasmine-bordered shadows. I realized that we had been surrounded by cats ever since we started walking. They now trailed her in unison like a row of ducklings down the sidewalk.**

**â€œI DIDNâ€™T KNOW YOU WERE A CAT PERSON!â€ I yelled hopelessly.**

**She laughed and raised a long middle finger into the air without turning around. I sighed and began walking in the other direction back to my hotel. I opened my phone to a new text message from Clarissa. It didnâ€™t say anything; sheâ€™d only sent three cat emojis with their tails in the air. I marveled at how little I knew what in the hell was going on. *I just stroked a human tail. That really happened.* And yet, perversely, I couldnâ€™t wait for the next day.**

***....Any secrets youâ€™d like to share with meâ€¦***

**Iâ€™ll come cleanâ€“that night wasnâ€™t the first time I googled â€œhumans with tailsâ€. There had been drunken nights alone that I obsessed over the idea. My thoughts were ransacked by half-humanoids risen from primordial tetrapods, dripping with sea-foam and tails dragging in the sand. I told you I was a weird guy. To this point, the greatest harm all this had done was butcher my online algorithmsâ€“I would get ads for kinky Halloween costumes, which routinely raised some eyebrows.**

***She could be a government spy on some troll-job,* I thought to myself. The idea tormented me for several hours. What was worse, I thought, the CIA using search history and store-bought accessories to play with my mind, or the possibility that I had met some kind of hybrid human with a rope of flesh swinging from her backside? The little bit of ganja I had left made my speculations thicker and more confusing. She had to be real. Why would the government waste time mind-fucking a guy from a band named Nineteeneightyfornicate? I went from that to wondering what she ate when she was stoned.**

**Before I knew it, I was stepping out onto the curb in front of her house in my black knock-off Christian Diors. Who was this profane intruder in Provo? An agent *provo*cateur, I grinned to myself. I didnâ€™t know there could be neighborhoods with trees in the desert. Seemed like the Mormons were pretty good landscapers when they werenâ€™t busy granting all their wives eternal life. Who knew! Clarissa lived in a blue house with a quaint little front porch, one of those places that really has the picture-book mailbox with a perfect red lever pointed upwards.**

**â€œWere you tailing me earlier?â€**

**Clarissaâ€™s voice came out of nowhere, disembodied. I looked around me wildly, my unease ratcheting up several notches. A hand rested on my shoulder from behind; I wheeled around.**

**â€œChill out, freak,â€ Clarissa laughed. She looked at the tree next to her, brushing off some twigs. â€œMy nest is up *there*.â€**

**â€œYourâ€“nest?â€**

**â€œItâ€™s a joke, heard of those before?â€**

**I suddenly noticed she was wearing a yellow Walkman cassette player. We always BS that if we meet a chick with a portable cassette player, weâ€™ll automatically drop to one knee, no questions asked.**

**â€œSo youâ€™re that much of a dork that you listen to cassette tapes in 2020?!â€**

**â€œAnd youâ€™re telling me you donâ€™t have one on you right now?â€**

**Wordlessly, I raised my bandâ€™s cassette tape out of my pocket.**

**â€œGive me that,â€ she laughed, snatching it out of my hand. â€œMaybe we *are* a match!â€**

**I followed her inside.**

**â€œMy roommates are out for the weekendâ€â€“glancing at the couchâ€“â€you can just shove all that shit over, sorry. We have beer, lemonade, soda...or maybe you like the harder stuff?â€**

**I settled in and tried to relax, taking in what was around me. Nothing odd really. There was a crystal salt lamp whose warm glow looked afloat in the dim room. I could faintly sniff sage. A white cat met my gaze and darted out of sight, desperate to be forgotten.**

**â€œYou donâ€™t get many visitâ€“â€**

**The sentence was robbed from my throat. Clarissa was putting a glass of Jack Daniels on the table, naked beside the burgundy lingerie faintly interrupting her skin. I could see the thing in plain sightâ€“it was moving from side to side in a sort of carefree, feline attitude, *curling* back on itself this way and that, hairless and freckled as it tapered to its tip. It was a magnificent tail, too magnificent to be an accident. I closed my eyes and took a shot of the Jack.**

**â€œI know what youâ€™re thinking,â€ Clarissa smiled. She sat down next to me, running her hand along my shoulder. â€œYouâ€™re thinking â€˜itâ€™s impossible, this canâ€™t actually be happening.â€™â€**

**â€œYou must be psychic,â€ I shot back dryly.**

**â€œYouâ€™re thinking,â€ she pressed on, â€œthat science eliminates the possibility of my existence.â€**

**I didnâ€™t say anything.**

**â€œWhatâ€™s wrong, rock star, you donâ€™t want to play along? I know that you know it allâ€“how they say a human tail is only an abomination of the coccyx, a *vestige* of the behind that we all left behind...right?â€**

**â€œWhat are you getting at here, Clarissa?â€**

**She took a swig of lemonade and rolled the juice around her mouth, her gaze unbroken.**

**â€œNothing you havenâ€™t already thought of ten thousand times, but Iâ€™ll humor you. If the only reason humans donâ€™t have tails is because of some kind of disabled gene-signal, then the chances of more than one being on the planet is like one in billions. So if you realized there were *others like you*, that hypothesis would suddenly be on very thin ice.â€**

**My blood ran cold. I leaned all the way back on the sofa until my eyes were looking at the ceiling. The clustered nerve-endings were firing off in tingles that made it hard for me to resist the urge to let it squirm beneath me. All of my practiced methods for controlling the thing were failing. It was as if it somehow sensed another of its kind and now had license to awaken. Sheâ€™d caught me by the tail.**

**Clarissa leaned over me, her face close to mine. â€œShow it to me,â€ she whispered.**

**No one had set eyes on it outside of my parents; I hadnâ€™t seen them since they put me up for adoption. I sat up, pulled the back of my shirt up and leaned over. Her eyes felt like hot embers across its naked surface. She lifted it between her fingers, held it in her palm, caressed it. I suddenly noticed how heavily I was breathing.**

**â€œThere are many of us, you know,â€ she said softly.**

**â€œHow many?â€**

**Clarissa paused. â€œI donâ€™t know, to be honest. But a lot. I met them in the genetic labs outside Salt Lake.â€**

**â€œWait, geneticâ€“â€**

**â€œShhh!â€ She put a finger to my lips and straddled me, pulling my hands through her blue hair. â€œWeâ€™ll talk about it later.â€**

**I clutched her swaying tail and let its smoothness run through my fingers.**

**â€œWeâ€™re a match,â€ she giggled, â€œa match made in some dirty heaven.â€**

**That evening, for the first time in my life, I surrendered fully to whatever it is that I am. Clarissa hasnâ€™t left my side since; weâ€™re in Cheyenne now. Thereâ€™s not a day that goes by where I donâ€™t think: Iâ€™ve never been happierâ€“or more deeply, inconsolably frightened.**

title: Buffett's advice to children: When you do these three things, you are not far away from success

1\. Do what you don't want others to do Â 

Â 

Buffett also told his son, "Don't do what other people do. Do what you love." Â 

Â 

Buffett once gave his son Peter only $90,000, but he gave him a supportive, encouraging and inducing environment.Â Â He encouraged Peter: If you want to live a colorful life, try to learn all the things that interest you.Â Â He urged Peter to look inside himself and find his passion.Â Â Buffett: Figuring out what you're passionate about is a painstaking, arcane process that requires a lot of freedom, and parental pressure can backfire.Â Â It was such an environment and painstaking parents that made Peter a successful composer today.Â

title: To be successful, don't make excuses
body:
The no-excuses approach may seem cold and impersonal, but it can bring out the best in a person.Â Â No matter who you are, you don't need excuses. When you fail, you make mistakes. When we complain, we are actually making excuses for ourselves.Â Â The only good thing about making excuses is that I can't do it for a reason.Â Â But this comfort is fatal, it tells itself: I can not overcome the difficulties caused by this objective condition.Â Â Under the guidance of this psychological suggestion, they will no longer think about the way to overcome difficulties and complete tasks, even if it is easy to achieve the goal as long as the Angle of change. Â 

Â 

For enterprises, this should always adhere to the concept.Â Â Companies need people with no excuses.Â Â How many people spend precious time and energy on finding a good excuse and forget their duties and responsibilities!Â Â Looking for excuses is just to cover up their own fault, the responsibility they should bear to the society or others.Â Â Such a person will not become a competent employee in the enterprise, nor can the enterprise expect and trust the employee;Â Â Is not a person you can trust or respect in society.Â Â Such a person is doomed to be nothing but a failure. Â 

Â 

Making excuses for everything is a fatal weakness in human nature. Once making excuses becomes a habit of your life, your work will be slow and ineffective.Â Â By abandoning the habit of making excuses, you will not be frustrated by problems at work, and you can even learn a lot of problem-solving skills at work, so that excuses will be further away from you and success will be closer and closer. Â 

Â 

The stupidest thing in the world is to find excuses to pass the buck.Â Â It's dangerous to get into the habit of finding all sorts of excuses in your life to justify what's going wrong. Â

title: Everyone has the ability to break through their own barriers
body:
Unwilling to think, unwilling to work hard, encounter a little difficulty on the give up. Â 

Â 

There is an idea in psychology that we encounter obstacles in our lives for a variety of reasons, but ultimately the biggest obstacle is ourselves. Â 

Â 

Partly because we like to set our own limits. Â 

Â 

Long-term failure in the past makes people have learned helplessness, which hits their self-confidence. Every time they encounter something challenging, they will be used to lack confidence and label themselves. Â 

Â 

On the other hand, a person's low self-awareness will also cause their own obstacles. Â 

Â 

The world in our eyes is not the objective world itself, but a reflection of the objective world in our eyes. Â 

Â 

You with what kind of mentality to map, your world will be what kind of. Â 

Â 

Maslow, the humanistic psychologist, said: Â 

Â 

If the state of mind changes, the attitude changes;Â Â Attitudes change, habits change;Â Â Habits change, character changes;Â Â When your character changes, your life changes. Â 

Â 

Nine out of ten things go wrong in life. Look at them positively instead of pessimistically, and your life will be much better. Â 

Â 

When confronted with something uncontrollable or unchangeable, the greatest harm lies not in the event itself, but in the attitude towards it. Â 

Â 

As long as we can look at it dialectically and maintain a positive attitude, we can also transform the crisis into invisible. Â
